citation.biblCit: Population Research Laboratory, 2016, "Alberta Survey, 2015B", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10858, UAL Dataverse, V1

AuthEnty.affiliation: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

stdyInfo.abstract: The Population Research Laboratory (PRL) administered the 2015 Alberta Survey B. This survey of households across the province of Alberta continues to enable academic researchers, government departments, and non-profit organizations to explore a wide range of topics in a structured research framework and environment. Sponsors’ research questions are asked together with demographic questions in a telephone interview of Alberta households.

dataColl.sampProc: The main feature of the sampling design was a two-stage selection process: first, based on a selection of households, and second, the selection of a respondent within each household. The Alberta Survey B aimed for a total sample size of 1,200 households across Alberta, with a minimum of 400 respondents in Metropolitan Edmonton, 400 i n Metropolitan Calgary, and 400 from the remainder of the province (other Alberta). The target population are persons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, are living in a dwelling unit that could be contacted by direct dialling. The PRL used a Random-Digit Dialling (RDD) approach to ensure that respondents had an equal chance to be contacted whether or not their household was listed in a telephone directory. The PRL has developed a database of eight-digit telephone banks covering the Edmonton and Calgary metropolitan areas, as well as the remainder of the province. By area, the identified working banks are randomly selected with replacement and a randomly generated set of two digits between 00-99 is appended to each selection. Duplicate telephone numbers were purged from the computer list. Within the household, one eligible person was selected as the respondent.
dataColl.weight: The sample sizes of completed interviews obtained for Metropolitan Edmonton, Metropolitan Calgary, and Other Alberta are not always proportional to the current Alberta population they are meant to represent. Therefore, statistical weights were calculated for the Alberta Survey B 2015 sample data using population estimates for 2014.

anlyInfo.respRate: Response rates are calculated percentages representing the number of people who participated in the survey divided by the number selected in the eligible sample. The response rate for 2015 Alberta Survey B was 19.6%. The method used in this study is calculated as the number of completed interviews divided by the number of completed interviews, refusals, incompletes, and language problems.
anlyInfo.EstSmpErr: This study is based on a sample of adults in Alberta rather than the total population of adults in Alberta. All of the descriptive statistics, such as means and percentages, which are calculated using the sample data, could be subject to sampling error. The sampling error is a measure of the validity of the descriptive statistics that are observed in a sample. The estimated sampling error, at the 95% confidence level, for an area sample of 1,211 households assuming a 50/50 binomial percentage distribution is plus or minus 2.8 percentage points. Survey estimates for the subsample of 400 are estimated to be within plus or minus 5.0 percentage points, at the 95% confidence level.

var.name: zseqnumB
var.labl: Survey Identification Number

var.name: primary$
var.labl: Quota distribution

var.name: strata
var.labl: Area of the Province

var.name: sex1
var.labl: Gender of Respondent

var.name: a1
var.labl: Before today, have you heard about CASA, or Child, Adolescent and Family Mental Health?

var.name: a2
var.labl: Do you think you might recommend CASA to someone that needs it?

var.name: a3
var.labl: Has anyone in your immediate family needed services from childrens' mental health programs?

var.name: a4
var.labl: Did you access services from CASA (for your immediate family)?

var.name: a5
var.labl: In general, how helpful was that service to you and/or your family?

var.name: a6
var.labl: How important do you think it is to have (CASA) sites that are close to the communities that need them?

var.name: a7x
var.labl: (K2a) How many children under the age of 18 live in your household?

var.name: a7a
var.labl: Does your child/any of your children have a mental health concern?

var.name: a7b
var.labl: Do you feel you have access to the services you need to support your child(ren)s mental wellness?

catgry.labl: Not applicable, no mental health concern (volunteered)

var.name: b1b
var.labl: Are you aware that Alberta has an organ and tissue donation registry that allows residents to indicate their consent to donate tissue and organs after death?

var.name: b1c
var.labl: Please indicate your position on the following: an organ donation system where everyone would be considered a potential organ and tissue donor after death unless they have previously specifically stated they do not wish to donate their organs or tissues?

var.name: b1d
var.labl: How do you feel about discussing your wishes about organ and tissue donation after death with your friends and family?

var.name: b1e
var.labl: Based on your understanding, in a situation where a person who has joined the organ donation registry has died, but his/her family does not want organ donation to proceed, whose wishes are followed?

catgry.labl: The wishes of the family who oppose organ donation
The wishes of the deceased person to become an organ donor

var.name: b1f
var.labl: In your opinion, in a situation where a person who has joined the organ donation registry has died, but his/her family does not want organ donation to proceed, whose wishes SHOULD be followed?

catgry.labl: The wishes of the deceased person to become an organ donor
The wishes of the family who oppose organ donation

var.name: b2a
var.labl: A public appeal for an organ is an acceptable method for a person to get a transplant?

var.name: b2b
var.labl: Public appeals for an organ are unfair because not everyone is able to make them?

var.name: b2c
var.labl: Public appeals for an organ are acceptable because people should try to help themselves?

var.name: b2d
var.labl: Public appeals for an organ are acceptable because when one person gets an organ the waiting line is shortened which helps the others who are waiting?

var.name: b2e
var.labl: Should the potential donor be anonymous to the recipient or should they get to know each other?

catgry.labl: They should get to know each other before the transplant
They should get to know each other after the transplant

var.name: b2f
var.labl: Should public appeals for organs give the organ to the person who made the appeal or to the person at the top of the waiting list (i.e., the sickest or the one who has waited longest)?

catgry.labl: The person who made the appeal
Public appeals should not be allowed
The person at the top of the waiting list

var.name: b2g
var.labl: If a person registered as a donor before the brain injury, do you think that this consent to donate after death also includes consent to receive drugs before death whose only benefit is to help keep the organs healthy enough to be transplanted?

var.name: b2h
var.labl: Do you think that giving drugs before death for the purpose of keeping the person's organs healthy enough to be transplanted is in the person's best interests?

var.name: b3a
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase organ and tissue donation from deceased donors: Reimbursing funeral expenses of the donor?

var.name: b3b
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase organ and tissue donation from deceased donors: Providing a tax break or credit to the donors estate?

var.name: b3c
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase organ and tissue donation from deceased donors: Providing a monetary payment (cash) to the donors estate?

var.name: b3d
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase organ and tissue donation from deceased donors: Providing a small payment (cash) to people who join the donation registry?

var.name: b4a
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase kidney donation from living donors: Providing a tax break or credit to a person after the kidney has been removed?

var.name: b4b
var.labl: Would you support any of the following strategies to increase kidney donation from living donors: Providing a monetary payment (cash) directly to the person after the kidney has been removed?

var.name: b5
var.labl: Do you think physicians in Canada should have an obligation to treat patients (e.g., provide follow-up care) after they return home from paying to receive an organ transplant operation abroad?

var.name: b6
var.labl: Do you think physicians in Canada should have a duty to support their patients efforts to go abroad to pay for an organ transplant, by providing, for example, pre-procedure testing, or antibiotic prescriptions?

var.name: b7a
var.labl: How concerned are you about Canadians purchasing organs and receiving organ transplant operations abroad?

var.name: b7b
var.labl: How concerned are you about Canadians who return home needing follow-up care will use Canadian health system resources and may queue-jump in the process?

var.name: b7c
var.labl: How concerned are you about the risk that Canadians who receive organ transplants abroad may bring home infections or other communicable diseases?

var.name: b7d
var.labl: How concerned are you about potential ethical implications for destination countries (e.g., potential exploitation and harm to those providing their organs, local access to health care, source of organs, etc.)?

var.name: b8
var.labl: If a Canadian physician is aware that their patient has travelled abroad to illegally purchase an organ and receive an organ transplant, should there be an obligation on the physician to disclose the names of the patient to a governmental authority?

var.name: b9a
var.labl: What approaches to the consent process of researchers needing biological samples would you be comfortable with: Consent given by the donor prior to death to use the samples for research?

var.name: b9b
var.labl: What approaches to the consent process of researchers needing biological samples would you be comfortable with: Consent given by the donors next of kin to use the samples in research?

var.name: b9c
var.labl: What approaches to the consent process of researchers needing biological samples would you be comfortable with: No consent needed to use the samples in research so long as there is approval to use the samples by an ethical oversight body?

var.name: b10a
var.labl: What consent methods for use of an organ donor's health information record after death would you be comfortable with: Consent given by the donor prior to death to use the information in research?

var.name: b10b
var.labl: What consent method for use of an organ donor's health information record after death would you be comfortable with: Consent given by the donors next of kin to use the information in research?

var.name: b10c
var.labl: What consent method for use of an organ donor's health information record after death would you be comfortable with: No consent given to use the information in research as long as there is approval to use the information by an ethical oversight body?

var.name: b11a
var.labl: As one of your doctor's patients, how comfortable are you with the idea that the drug you are prescribed will be determined by random like flipping a coin?

var.name: b11b
var.labl: Do you think that the doctor should obtain consent from his patients to be part of the research project before he determines whether the patient should randomly be given Drug A or Drug B?

var.name: b11c
var.labl: How comfortable are you with the doctor assigning patients to either Drug A or Drug B without initially telling them about the research study and seeking their consent at a later time?

var.labl: Do you hunt waterfowl?

var.name: c3
var.labl: Would you be willing to mentor a family member or friend in waterfowl hunting?

var.name: c6

catgry.labl: Not applicable - Respondent did not answer questions on Waterfowl Hunting after C1

var.name: c7a

catgry.labl: Not applicable - Respondent did not answer questions on Waterfowl Hunting after C1

var.name: c8

catgry.labl: Not applicable - Respondent did not answer questions on Waterfowl Hunting after C1

var.name: c11a
var.labl: Do you still consider waterfowl hunting a good thing to do?

var.name: c12
var.labl: Would you be supportive of a child, family or close friend taking up waterfowl hunting?
